ORAL ANSWERS TO QUESTIONS

BUS AND MRT FARE INCREASES


    1. Mr R. Ravindran asked the Minister for Transport why has the Public Transport Council approved fare increases by the bus and train operators in view of the present economic difficulties faced by many Singaporeans.

Column: 10



    2. Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan asked the Minister for Transport (a) what is the Public Transport Council's (PTC) justification for the increase in bus and MRT fares during such difficult times, when there are expected increases in car parking charges and goods and services tax and when the transport companies are still reporting very decent profits and (b) whether deferring the PTC's increases by six months to a year will put the operators under water.

    3. Dr Ong Seh Hong asked the Minister for Transport if he (a) is satisfied that the transport companies' justification for fare hike is to meet rising operating cost; (b) will elucidate, in the light of a lower corporate tax, reasonably stable oil prices, cut-back in Government charges and lower unit labour cost, the factors causing the operating cost to increase; and (c) will state what have the companies done to improve their cost effectiveness and productivity instead of raising fares to maintain their profitability.

Column: 10

PUBLIC TRANSPORT SECTOR
(Liberalisation)


    4. Dr Ong Seh Hong asked the Minister for Transport if he will consider liberalising the transport sector to allow for more service providers to come in to further enhance competition and more efficient management of resources and hence reducing the public transport cost.

    The Senior Minister of State for Transport (Mr Khaw Boon Wan) (for the Minister for Transport): Mr Speaker, Sir, Question Nos. 1 to 4 pertain to the recent transport fare increases approved by the Public Transport Council. Members would like to know the justification for such a decision and whether they could be avoided. Since those Questions were filed, Mr Tan Soo Khoon and several others have tabled a Motion on Public Transport Fares, which is scheduled for debate this afternoon.

    With your permission, Sir, and the Members' understanding, my Minister would like to answer the four Questions

Column: 11

during the course of the debate on the Motion, please.

    Mr Speaker: It is a rather unusual request, but I will allow the Minister to reply to the Questions when he speaks on the Motion.

Column: 11

MALAYSIAN PRIME MINISTER'S INTENDED RESIGNATION
(Impact on Malaysia-Singapore relations)


    5. Mdm Ho Geok Choo asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs as the Malaysian Prime Minister is going to step down before the end of next year, does his Ministry envisage any significant change in the direction of Malaysia-Singapore relations over the next few months and what will be the shape of Malaysia-Singapore relations over the long term after he has stepped down as Prime Minister.

    6. Mr Gan Kim Yong asked the Minister for Foreign Affairs if he will provide an assessment of the impact on bilateral relations with Malaysia resulting from Dr Mahathir's intended resignation and the change of political leadership.

    The Second Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Lee Yock Suan) (for the Minister for Foreign Affairs): Mr Speaker, Sir, with your consent, could I respond to Question Nos. 5 and 6 together, on behalf of the Minister?

    Mr Speaker: Yes.

    Mr Lee Yock Suan: Sir, the Members have asked about the immediate and long-term impact of Dr Mahathir's resignation on Singapore-Malaysia relations.

    In comments to the media on 1st July 2002, DPM Dr Tony Tan and DPM Lee Hsien Loong had both emphasised that Dr Mahathir's decision to step down in 2003 would not affect our bilateral relations with Malaysia. I fully agree. The three previous leadership changes in

Column: 12

Malaysia had been smooth and orderly. There is no reason to expect that this transition will be any different. Dr Mahathir remains Prime Minister until after the OIC Meeting in Kuala Lumpur in October 2003. He has confirmed Deputy Prime Minister Datuk Seri Abdullah Badawi as his successor. DPM Badawi is well known to us. We see no reason for any significant change in bilateral relations either immediately or in the long-term. The fundamentals of Singapore-Malaysia relations are not dependent on personalities. As close neighbours, we will work with whoever is in charge.

Column: 12

ELECTRONIC AND INTERNET BANKING
(Enhancement of security of depositors' accounts)


    7. Mr Ahmad Mohd Magad asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (a) what steps will the Government take to enhance security of bank depositors' accounts and to prevent erosion of confidence in electronic and on-line banking in the light of several recent hacking incidents and (b) whether the Government will introduce harsher penalties as deterrent to such acts.

    The Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance (Mr Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, MAS has promulgated security guidelines on electronic and internet banking for the banking industry. The security standards which banks have to comply will include:

    i) maintaining robust risk management controls and security practices;

    ii) deploying strong cryptography to protect customer data; and

    iii) enhancing surveillance, incident response and systems recovery capabilities.

    As part of the audit and internal monitoring process, auditors have a duty to evaluate bank compliance with these security guidelines. MAS also maintains its own programme of on-site inspections and off-site reviews.

Column: 13



    Banks are required to assess the risks relating to their on-line banking products and adopt appropriate security control measures to address and mitigate the risks involved. They are directly responsible for the safety and soundness of the services and systems they provide to their customers.

    Internet banking, as with other forms of on-line banking, is not without risks. These risks generally relate to impersonation, stealing ID or PIN information, computer hacking, forging access to accounts and fraudulent transactions. The safety of on-line banking is dependent on the security systems of the bank and the precautions that customers take to safeguard their User ID and PIN, as well as protecting the PCs they use. For example, customers should install firewall and anti-virus software on their PCs to block out hackers, and log off their computers when not in use.

    Regarding the recent hacking incident, which affected a number of DBS customers, the Police are still carrying out their investigation.

    According to DBS, which has been conducting its own internal investigation, its findings were that the bank's own Internet system had not been hacked, but it was the customers' PCs which had been hacked. By accessing the customers' PCs, the hacker(s) had been able to capture the PINs and IDs of these customers. The hacker(s) then used the captured customer information to access their accounts to make fraudulent withdrawal transfers.

    The Police and DBS have advised the public on certain precautionary measures to take and good security practices to adopt when conducting on-line banking.

    Penalties for hacking into bank systems are already prescribed in the Computer Misuse Act. These penalties have been designed to take account of the severity of the offence and the actual or potential damage caused. For example, if it can be proved that a hacker broke into a "protected computer system" relating to

Column: 14

banking and financial services, the Act provides for an enhanced maximum penalty of a $100,000 fine, or 20 years' imprisonment or both. In addition to the criminal penalties, the court may order a convicted offender to pay monetary compensation for any damage caused by the offence to the computer system or data.

Column: 14

CONSUMER CREDIT BUREAU

(Use of customers' personal financial data)



    8. Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung asked the Deputy Prime Minister and Minister for Finance what are the conditions imposed by the Monetary Authority of Singapore for the use of personal financial data of customers in the setting up and operation of the Consumer Credit Bureau by the Association of Banks in Singapore.

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Mr Speaker, Sir, there has been an active public debate on the establishment of the credit bureau and, particularly, on confidentiality. Many Singaporeans are concerned that the credit bureau will lead to a dilution in confidentiality of banking information. They fear that commercial banks, with the help of the bureau, will have access to client's information about the state of his or her finances that they were not privy to before. These are reasonable concerns and deserve to be addressed squarely.

    The Banking Act provides the legal framework on the use of customer information. This provision is found in paragraph 7 of Part II of the Sixth Schedule. Banks are only permitted to disclose credit-related information to the recognised credit bureau such as personal details, the type and number of credit facilities granted, repayment trends and bankruptcy records. Banks are not allowed to disclose deposit information. This includes any funds, safe deposit boxes or safe custody arrangements of a customer under management by a bank. This is an important distinction between credit-related information and deposit information. The credit bureau and other MAS approved institutions participating in the

Column: 15

bureau will only have access to a customer's credit history. The purpose for such access is restricted to the assessment of credit-worthiness of customers, and further disclosure to any other person is prohibited.

    Furthermore, a credit bureau that the banks want to use must demonstrate its ability to address financial privacy concerns competently, and to discharge its role effectively in providing accurate reports. MAS will only recognise and gazette the credit bureau when the concerns are adequately addressed, possibly in the form of a written code of conduct for the bureau.

    Should a credit bureau fail to maintain the high standards expected of it, MAS will not hesitate to cancel its recognition of the bureau. Once this happens, it becomes illegal for banks to provide customer information to the credit bureau.

    MAS recognises that the Consumer Credit Bureau has an important role to play in the financial industry. With the establishment of a credit bureau, members will have more information to anticipate potential bad debt situations before they occur. They will be able to better manage their overall level of bad debts. Studies have also shown that credit bureaus in other countries have enabled credit providers to differentiate between customers, and manage and price them accordingly.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung (Sembawang): Sir, can the DPM assure all credit card members that the information that they have supplied to these agencies will not be disclosed without proper safeguards, such as their identity would not be disclosed? And if their credit worthiness is disclosed, their transaction record should not be disclosed, but rather whether they were in good credit or bad credit. In other words, whether or not they can afford to pay for their charges, but not the specifics of what and how they are spending, because many credit agencies have been selling such information, so that people

Column: 16

can build shopping profiles and so on of credit card users.

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: Yes, Mr Speaker, Sir, the purpose of the credit bureau is not to sell information so that people can build your profile. It is to establish your borrowing track record, whether you are paying back on time, whether you have defaulted, or whether you are bankrupt. You have to provide the name because if you do not provide the name, you cannot start to retrieve data. But what is associated with that name is not your deposit information, it is not how much money you have, it is what accounts you have. It is only things like the number and type of credit facilities granted, the repayment trends, whether you are repaying, bankruptcy records, and whether you have ever gone bankrupt or not.

    Assoc. Prof. Chin Tet Yung: But what about transaction records?

    Mr Lee Hsien Loong: I do not believe that transaction records will be covered.

Column: 16

SINGAPORE BUSINESS FEDERATION
(Mandatory membership)


    9. Ms Indranee Rajah asked the Minister for Trade and Industry (a) why is there a need for local companies with a paid up share capital of S$500,000 or more and foreign companies with an authorised share capital of S$500,000 or more to be compelled by law to become members of the Singapore Business Federation and to pay subscription fees, and (b) why have they been deprived of the option to choose whether or not to become members of the said Federation.

    The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG George Yong-Boon Yeo): Mr Speaker, Sir, the establishment of the Singapore Business Federation with mandatory membership was proposed by the former Singapore Federation of Chambers of Commerce and Industry (SFCCI), as a new apex organisation to represent Singapore's business interests more effectively, both locally and abroad. In response to SFCCI's recommendation and after many

Column: 17

months of consultation with members of the local and international business community in Singapore, the Government introduced the Singapore Business Federation Bill, providing for mandatory membership of the SBF of all local companies with a paid-up capital of $0.5 million and above, and foreign companies with an authorised capital of $0.5 million and above. The Bill was passed by this House in October last year, and the SBF was formed in April this year.

    I explained to this House last year during the debate on the SBF Bill that we supported SFCCI's recommendation that membership of the SBF should be mandatory as the earlier practice of voluntary membership by business chambers and associations had not been effective. The business community had remained fragmented despite our best efforts, and lacked a strong and united private sector umbrella organisation. Compulsory membership would ensure that the SBF has a strong membership base, and has the mandate of the entire business community.

    Compulsory membership of business chambers can also be found in other countries. In France, Germany and Brazil, for example, chambers of commerce have legislative rights to collect fees from businesses. To ensure that this requirement will not be unduly onerous on our companies, we have exempted small companies, partnerships and sole proprietorships from having to join and contribute to the SBF. Hence, only local companies with paid-up capital and foreign companies with authorised capital of $0.5 million and above are required to be members of the SBF.

    We use paid-up capital because it is a simple criterion and generally correlated with size. MTI, together with the pro-tem committee of the SBF, did consider other criteria like profitability, annual turnover and employment size, but came to the conclusion that, whatever criterion or set of criteria we used, there would be difficulties wherever the line was drawn. In the end, we decided on paid-up capital

Column: 18

as the simplest and least contentious criterion. Recognising, however, that exemptions may be clearly justified based on this criterion, the Act enables the Minister to allow them. To date, SBF has preferred not to recommend any exempted category because such exemption might cause many others not exempted to feel that they too should be exempted. As the SBF has only recently been formed, it is still collecting feedback. If SBF decides that there should be exemptions based on clear criteria and recommends them to me, I will consider them carefully.

    Ms Indranee Rajah (Tanjong Pagar): What would be the position with regard to companies which are not trading, for example, investment holding companies? Would this be an appropriate category for an exemption?

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: I would prefer that such feedback be given to SBF and for SBF to look at the full implications and then put up its recommendations to me. I should not go behind the SBF to second guess what its recommendations should be.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee (Bishan-Toa Payoh): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister to consider that for companies which have a paid-up capital of $500,000, but actually became defunct or dormant because their business dealings are no more active, should be exempted from paying subscription fees.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Sir, if these companies are de-registered, then, obviously, the compulsory membership will not apply.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee: These companies may not have been de-registered, but they are active companies with no real trading or activities going on. They are just dormant companies.

    BG George Yong-Boon Yeo: Sir, it is not easy to establish criteria for dormancy. But if such criterion can be established and the dormant status incontrovertibly

Column: 19

defined, then I am sure SBF would recommend these companies to me, and I will consider them appropriately.

NEW ELECTRICITY MARKET


    10. Mr Andy Gan Lai Chiang asked the Minister for Trade and Industry whether the new electricity market to be launched later this year will attract the participation of a sufficient number of generation companies so as to avoid an oligopolistic market.

    The Minister of State for Trade and Industry (Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat) (for the Minister for Trade and Industry): Mr Speaker, Sir, we have four generation licensees selling into the pool at the moment. Two other generation licensees have indicated that they are planning to commission their plants sometime in 2005.

    Despite the number of generation licensees, about 90% of the total installed capacity in our system is concentrated in three big generation companies. These companies will have market power for about 12 years.

    These companies can use this market power to bid up pool prices. To prevent this, we will impose vesting contracts on the generation companies to curb their market power. Vesting contracts place an obligation on the generation companies to sell part of their capacity into the pool at a specified price. Generation companies will have to compete to sell the rest of the capacity that is not vested into the pool. With market power removed, the pool price is likely to be competitive.

    We will also prohibit the large gencos from expanding beyond their current licensed capacity so long as vesting contracts are in place. This is to ensure that the concentration of capacity and market power in the generation companies is not perpetuated. New capacity to meet demand growth will have to be met

Column: 20

by companies other than the big three generation companies.

    Mr Andy Gan Lai Chiang (Marine Parade): Sir, if we say that liberalisation does not necessarily mean lower prices for consumers, it means competitive prices, as what the Minister of State has just mentioned. So electricity need not be cheaper. Presently, we have installed capacity of about 11,000 megawatts of power and total consumption is only 8,000 megawatts. Senoko Power, Power Seraya and Tuas Power all account for 79% of capacity. On the demand side, we are planning ---

    Mr Speaker: Are you asking a question, Mr Gan?

    Mr Andy Gan Lai Chiang: I am sorry, Sir. I just want to explain my question. We have more and more electricity being consumed by households. Are there any educational programmes to educate Singaporeans on the cost of electricity and the rate of usage, so that we can take more responsibilities on ourselves?

    Mr Raymond Lim Siang Keat: Sir, the answer is yes, Power Supply has been conducting educational programmes to educate consumers on how best to use electricity.

SCHOLASTIC ASSESSMENT TEST (SAT)

    Mr Mah Bow Tan:

    Spalling concrete is the result of a deterioration process called carbonation whereby carbon dioxide diffuses into the concrete and forms carbonates when it reacts with the alkalis in the concrete. Carbonation reduces the level of alkalinity in the concrete, thus allowing the steel bars in the concrete to corrode. The corrosion causes the steel bars to expand forcing the concrete surrounding the steel to crack and spall, exposing the steel bar.

    Spalling concrete is a natural phenomenon and it occurs in all concrete buildings as the buildings age over time. It is not peculiar to any flat type or flats which were built in certain years or during a certain period.

    HDB flat owners who encounter spalling concrete problems in their flats can report them to their respective HDB Branch Offices. HDB will assist the flat owners to investigate the cause of the problem and recommend appropriate remedial action. For flat owners who have difficulty in finding a suitable repair contractor on their own, HDB will also assist to provide them with a list of repair contractors for them to negotiate with on a private basis.

    Under the lease, HDB flat owners are responsible for the repair of spalling concrete in their flats. As such, the Government cannot subsidise the repair cost for spalling concrete problems.
